summary: the most common cause of acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is respiratory infection. most studies of bacterial or viral cause in AECOPD have been conducted in western countries. chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is an obstructive lung disease caused by smoking and air pollution. 1,2 COPD patients often experience sudden aggravation of respiratory symptoms called acute exacerbation of COPD (AECOPD), and require additional treatment. the cause of admission was something other than AECOPD, such as heart failure, arrhythmia, acute pulmonary edema, acute pulmonary embolism, or pneumothorax. no laboratory or culture test was conducted within 24 hr of hospitalization; or 4) they showed mild to moderate exacerbation of COPD. data were analyzed using SPSS 20 software (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA) data were presented as meanstandard deviation or number and percent of each group. when events were classified by in-hospital mortality, chi-square test or Fisher's test was used for discrete data. antigen detection assays and polymerase chain reaction assays were performed on blood, sputum, urine, or naso- or oro-pharyngeal swab samples. a rapid antigen test was used to test to detect influenza. pathogen identification A bacterial pathogen was determined to be present if gram-positive or gram-negative bacteria were detected in a blood or sputum sample.
